facts.text: Sadashiv was murdered on November 29, 1957 in the courtyard of his house in village Nimgaon.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals arise out of an incident that took place on November 29, 1957, when one Sadashiv was murdered in the companyrtyard of his house in village Nimgaon.

facts.text: Four appellants armed with sticks went to the house of the deceased, dragged him out and beat him with sticks in the courtyard resulting in his death the next day at 5 p.m. at Bhandara Hospital.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the prosecution was that the four appellants, armed with sticks, went to the house of the deceased, dragged him out of the house and beat him with sticks in the companyrtyard and that as a result of the beating he died on the next day at about 5 p.m. at Bhandara Hospital.

facts.text: Police submitted report to Magistrate under s.173 CrPC along with relevant documents.

anchor.surface_text: After investigation, the police submitted their report to the Magistrate unders. 173 of the Code along with the relevant documents.

facts.text: Officer in charge furnished appellants with copy of police report under s.173(1), FIR under s.154, other documents including statements under s.161(3), and list of proposed witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: After forwarding the report, the officer in charge of the police station furnished the appellants with a companyy of the report forwarded under sub-s.  1  of s. 173, the First Information Report recorded under s. 154 and all other documents or relevant extracts thereof on which the prosecution proposed to rely, including the statements recorded under sub-S.  3  of S. 161 and also intimated them of the persons the prosecution proposed to. examine as its witnesses.

facts.text: Magistrate posted case for inquiry on February 10, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate posted the case for inquiry on February 10, 1958 and on that date the prosecution intimated that it did number intend to examine any witnesses in the Magistrates Court., ,

facts.text: Prosecution intimated no intention to examine any witnesses in Magistrate's Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate posted the case for inquiry on February 10, 1958 and on that date the prosecution intimated that it did number intend to examine any witnesses in the Magistrates Court., ,

facts.text: No objection raised by appellants to prosecution not examining witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants numberobjection was raised, to,that companyrse. But the Magistrate adjourned the inquiry to February 12, 1958,

facts.text: Magistrate adjourned inquiry to February 12, 1958 to consider if evidence necessary before commitment.

anchor.surface_text: But the Magistrate adjourned the inquiry to February 12, 1958, as he wanted to companysider whether any evidence was necessary to be recorded before companymitment.

facts.text: On February 12, 1958, Magistrate opined no witnesses need be examined, framed charges under s.302/34 and s.448 IPC, committed appellants to Sessions Court.

anchor.surface_text: On February 12, 1958, reexpressed his opinion that numberwitness need. be examined at that stage thereafter, he framed charges against accused appellants under s. 302, read with s. 34, of the Indian Penal Code, and also under s. 448 thereof and companymitted the appellants to the Sessions Court.

facts.text: Sessions Court prosecution evidence included 4 eye-witnesses PW 6,11,20,25; dying declaration Ex P-15 supported by PW 18,22,19; jail identification by PW 20,25; recoveries at instance of accused.

anchor.surface_text: Before the learned Sessions Judge the prosecution led four types of evidence, i.e.  1  eye-witnesses, namely, P.Ws. 6, 11, 20 and 25  2  dying declaration, Ex. P-15, supported by Ws. 18,22 and 19  3 -the identification of the appellants in jail by P.Ws. 20 and 25 and  4  recovery of various articles at, the instance of the accused-appellants.

facts.text: Defence examined four witnesses in Sessions Court.

anchor.surface_text: The defence examined four witnesses. On a companysideration of the entire evidence,

facts.text: Sessions Judge held prosecution case proved, appellants entered house and beat deceased causing 12 contused wounds, fracture of ribs, injury to lung, death due to shock and haemorrhage.

anchor.surface_text: the learned Sessions Judge held that,the prosecution, case had been amply borne out and that the four appellants entered into the house of the deceased and beat him in the manner described by the prosecution wit- nesses. As. numberless than 12 companyfused wounds were inflicted on the deceased, which resulted in the fracture of his ribs and injury to the lung,. and as the, doctor opined that the death was due to shock and haemorrhage resulting from said fracture,

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted appellants under s.302/34 IPC and sentenced to life imprisonment, and under s.448 IPC to 3 months RI.

anchor.surface_text: the learned Sessions Judge hold that the accused appellants were guilty of murder and companyvicted them under s.302, read with a. 34, Indian Penal Code,and he further companyvicted them, under s. 448 of the Indian Penal Code for trespassing into the house of the deceased. On these findings the learned Sessions Judge sentenced the appellants to undergo imprisonment for life on the first companynt and for 3 months rigorous imprisonment on the second companynt.

facts.text: Appellants appealed convictions to Bombay High Court at Nagpur.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants preferred an appeal against their companyvictions and sentences to the High Court of Bombay at Nagpur.

facts.text: Bombay High Court agreed with Sessions Judge on prosecution case but held guilty under s.304 Part I /34 IPC, reduced sentence to 10 years RI for appellant 1 and 7 years RI for appellants 2-4.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court, on a resurvey of the entire evidence, agreeing with the learned Sessions Judge, accepted the prosecution case, but they held that the appellants were guilty only under s. 304, Part 1, read with s. 34, Indian Penal Code, and in the result they reduced the sentence from life imprisonment to 10 years rigorous imprisonment in regard to appellant 1 and to 7 years rigorous imprisonment in regard to appellants 2 to 4.

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 57 of 1960 preferred by first appellant, No. 58 of 1960 by appellants 2 to 4, by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Against the said companyvictions and sentences, the appellants have preferred, by special leave, appeals to this Court. Criminal Appeal No. 57 of 1960 has been preferred by the first appellant and Criminal Appeal No. 58 of 1960 by appel- lants 2 to 4.

facts.text: Appellants contended Sessions and High Court did not properly appreciate evidence holding appellants committed offences.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the appellants raised before us the following two points  1  The Sessions Court and, on appeal, the High Court have number properly appreciated the evidence and the circumstances of the case in holding that the appellants had companymitted the offences.

facts.text: Appellants contended Magistrate had no jurisdiction to commit without examining witnesses under s.207A(4), defect not cured by s.532 or 537 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: 2  The trial and companyviction of the appellants by the Sessions Court were null and void, as the Magistrate had numberjurisdiction to companymit the appellants to Sessions without examining witnesses under sub-s.  4  of s. 207A of the Code and that, as the order of companymittal was without jurisdiction, the defect was number cured either under s. 532 or s. 537 of the Code.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected first contention as concurrent findings on facts not to be interfered with.

anchor.surface_text: The first question does number merit any companysideration. Both the companyrts below have, carefully companysidered the evidence adduced by the prosecution as well as the accused-appellants and have accepted the prosecution case. It is a well established practice of this Court number to interfere on questions of fact, particularly when they are companycurrent findings, except under exceptional circumstances.

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and order dated November 5/6, 1958 of Bombay High Court at Nagpur in Criminal Appeal No. 94 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 5/6, 1958, of the Bombay High Court at Nagpur in Criminal Appeal No. 94 of 1958.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by SUBBA RAO, J. on December 5, 1960.

issues.text: What is the correct interpretation of sub-section 4 of section 207A of the Code with respect to the Magistrate's duty to examine eye-witnesses produced by the prosecution and discretion to examine other witnesses

anchor.surface_text: question on the interpretation of the provisions of s. 207A of the Criminal Procedure Code  hereinafter referred to as the Code . The facts that have given rise to these appeals may be briefly stated.

issues.text: Whether sub-sections 6 and 7 of s. 207A impose taking of evidence as a condition precedent for commitment or discharge

anchor.surface_text: It is not permissible to create conflict by construction, when by an alternative construction all the three sub-sections can be harmonized and reconciled.

issues.text: Whether the Magistrate acted illegally in committing without taking any evidence such that the illegality requires curing under s. 537 even if jurisdiction exists

anchor.surface_text: it is not necessary to express our opinion whether even if the Magistrate acted illegally in committing an accused without taking any evidence, the said illegality is cured either by s. 537 of the Code or any other section thereof.

arguments.claim: The Sessions Court and, on appeal, the High Court have not properly appreciated the evidence and the circumstances of the case in holding that the appellants had committed the offences.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellants raised before us the following two points 1 The Sessions Court and, on appeal, the High Court have not properly appreciated the evidence and the circumstances of the case in holding that the appellants had committed the offences.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Penal Code,and he further companyvicted them, under s. 448 of the Indian Penal Code for trespassing into the house of the deceased. On these findings

arguments.court_reasoning: Both courts below carefully considered evidence and accepted prosecution case; well established practice not to interfere with concurrent findings except exceptional circumstances; no such circumstances here.

arguments.claim: The trial and conviction of the appellants by the Sessions Court were null and void, as the Magistrate had no jurisdiction to commit the appellants to Sessions without examining witnesses under sub-s. 4 of s. 207A of the Code.

anchor.surface_text: 2 The trial and conviction of the appellants by the Sessions Court were null and void, as the Magistrate had no jurisdiction to commit the appellants to Sessions without examining witnesses under sub-s. 4 of s. 207A of the Code

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Court. In practice the companymittal proceeding, whether intended by the Legislature or number, served another purpose, namely, it gave an opportunit

arguments.court_reasoning: Magistrate bound only to examine eye-witnesses actually produced; has discretion to examine others if necessary; jurisdiction exists to commit on documents alone if no production.

arguments.claim: As the order of commitment was without jurisdiction, the defect was not cured either under s. 532 or s. 537 of the Code.

anchor.surface_text: and that, as the order of commitment was without jurisdiction, the defect was not cured either under s. 532 or s. 537 of the Code.

arguments.claim: It could not have been the intention of the Legislature to permit the prosecution to keep back the eye-witnesses in the commitment court and therefore the word produced should be read as cited.

anchor.surface_text: To accept this interpretation is to substitute the word cited in place of the word produced such a construction is not permissible, especially, when the plain meaning of the word used by the Legislature is clear and unambiguous

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ocess unless, for reasons to be recorded, he deems it unnecessary to do so. At the companymencement of the inquiry, the Magistrate shall, when the acc

arguments.court_reasoning: Not permissible to substitute words when plain meaning clear and unambiguous; phrase 'if any' emphasizes prosecution may not produce any.

arguments.claim: Sub-ss. 6 and 7 indicate that taking of evidence by the Magistrate is a condition precedent for making an order of discharge or of commitment.

anchor.surface_text: But it is said that sub-ss. 6 and 7 indicate that taking of evidence by the Magistrate is a condition precedent for making an order of discharge or of commitment and, therefore, the provisions of Sub-s. 4 must be so construed as to impose a duty on the Magistrate to examine some witnesses.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: . State of Mysore  1 , State v. Andi Betankar  2 , Ghisa v. State  3   and Chandu Satyanarayana The State  4 .  2  The Magistrates power to examine ey

arguments.court_reasoning: 'When' denotes point of time not condition precedent; cannot create conflict when harmonious reading possible; would lead to anomaly if documents show innocence but must examine witnesses.

arguments.claim: By contrasting s.251A with s.207A, if construction not accepted that evidence mandatory, difference obliterated.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance is placed upon s. 251A of the Code relating to warrant cases whereunder the Magistrate is authorized, upon consideration of all the documents referred to in s. 173... By contrasting this provision with s. 207A, it is contended that if the construction put forward by learned counsel is not accepted, the obvious difference between the two procedures indicated by the Legislature would be obliterated.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rtant eye-witnesses, the companyrt would number be exercising its judicial discretion if it companymits the accused to sessions on the basis of docume

arguments.court_reasoning: Difference intentional: s.207A requires evidence in certain contingencies, s.251A none; not province of court to add conditions.

arguments.claim: Under the old procedure, commitment inquiry allowed testing witness credibility via discrepancies with s.161 statements and sessions evidence.

anchor.surface_text: In practice the commitment proceeding... served another purpose, namely, it gave an opportunity to the accused to test the credibility of witnesses by bringing out the discrepancies between their evidence in the committing court, the statements made by them to the police under s. 161 of the Code and the evidence given by them in the Court of Sessions.

arguments.claim: Legislature amended Code via s.207A to reduce delays from elaborate commitment proceedings by simplifying on police reports where documents suffice.

anchor.surface_text: The Legislature, in its wisdom, presumably thought that undue delay in the disposal of sessions cases was due to the elaborate and prolonged commitment proceedings and stepped in to amend the Code in that respect. The whole of s. 207A has been inserted by Act XXVI of 1955.

arguments.claim: Distinction between police report cases and others reasonable as police report includes thorough inquiry and documents furnished under s.173.

anchor.surface_text: This distinction between the two classes of cases had a reasonable factual basis. In the case of a police report, a thorough inquiry would have been made... The Magistrate in a proceeding instituted on police report would ordinarily be in a position, on the said material to understand the case of the prosecution...

arguments.claim: If words precise and unambiguous, expound in natural ordinary sense; first part of 207A(4): Magistrate shall take evidence of such persons, if any, as produced by prosecution as eye-witnesses to actual commission.

anchor.surface_text: One of the fundamental rules of interpretation is that if the words of a statute are in themselves precise and unambiguous no more is necessary than, to expound those words in their natural and ordinary sense... The first part of the sub-section reads The Magistrate shall then proceed to take the evidence of such persons, if any, as may be produced by the prosecution as witnesses to the actual commission of the offence alleged.

arguments.claim: Second part of 207A(4): Magistrate may take evidence of other witnesses if of opinion necessary in interests of justice; judicial discretion, reviewable if perverse.

anchor.surface_text: The wording of the second part of the sub-section is also without any ambiguity... No doubt the word may... imposes duty upon the Magistrate to take other evidence but that duty can arise only if he is of opinion that it is necessary in the interests of justice... Doubtless the discretion being a judicial one, it should be exercised reasonably by the Magistrate.

arguments.claim: 'Other witnesses' means witnesses other than those produced by prosecution, including eye-witnesses not produced; categories of witnesses explained.

anchor.surface_text: If so, what do the words other witnesses mean? Do they mean witnesses other than eye-witnesses or witnesses, eye-witnesses or not, other than those produced before the Magistrate, by the prosecution? ... The second part of the sub-section therefore confers a discretionary power on the Magistrate to examine any one or more of witnesses of all categories, including the eye-witnesses who have not been produced...

arguments.claim: Subs 6 and 7: 'when' denotes time, not condition precedent; read harmoniously with sub4, no mandatory evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Firstly, we cannot hold that the sub-sections impose any such condition. The argument is that the clause in subs. 6, namely, When the evidence referred to in subsection 4 has been taken is a condition precedent... The adverb when in the clause in the context denotes a point of time and not a condition precedent... It is not permissible to create conflict by construction, when by an alternative construction all the three sub-sections can be harmonized and reconciled.

arguments.claim: S.251A distinguished: no evidence required there, unlike contingencies in 207A; intentional difference.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance is placed upon s. 251A... By contrasting this provision with s. 207A, it is contended... We cannot agree with this contention. The difference between the two procedures is that, in a case covered by s. 207A, evidence will have to be taken under certain contingencies, whereas under s. 251A no evidence need be taken at all.

arguments.claim: In Macherla Hanumantha Rao, s.207A interpreted consistently: Magistrate not obliged to record any evidence; can discharge/commit on documents.

anchor.surface_text: We are fortified in our view by a decision of this Court in Macherla Hanumantha Rao v. The State of Andhra Pradesh... The magistrate then has to record the evidence of such witnesses as figure as eye-witnesses to the occurrence, and are produced before him. He has also the power... but he is not obliged to record any evidence.

arguments.claim: Propositions: 1. Magistrate bound only to eye-witnesses actually produced. 2. Duty to examine others if opinion necessary in justice. 3. Jurisdiction to commit/discharge on s.173 docs if no exam. 4. Judicial discretion reviewable.

anchor.surface_text: Our view could not be expressed in the following propositions 1 In a proceeding instituted on a police report, the Magistrate is bound to take evidence of only such eye-witnesses as are actually produced by the prosecution in court. 2 The Magistrate, if he is of opinion that it is in the interest of justice...

arguments.claim: Not necessary to decide if illegality in committing without evidence cured by s.537.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, it is not necessary to express our opinion whether even if the Magistrate acted illegally in committing an accused without taking any evidence, the said illegality is cured either by s. 537 of the Code or any other section thereof.

holdings.text: Supreme Court will not interfere with concurrent findings of fact by lower courts except in exceptional circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: The first question does number merit any companysideration. Both the companyrts below have, carefully companysidered the evidence adduced by the prosecution as well as the accused-appellants and have accepted the prosecution case. It is a well established practice of this Court number to interfere on questions of fact, particularly when they are companycurrent findings, except under exceptional circumstances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts carefully considered all evidence and accepted prosecution version; no exceptional circumstances present.

holdings.text: Under s.207A(4) first part, Magistrate bound to examine only eye-witnesses actually produced by prosecution as such.

anchor.surface_text: One of the fundamental rules of interpretation is that if the words of a statute are in themselves precise and unambiguous no more is necessary than, to expound those words in their natural and ordinary sense

holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal interpretation of unambiguous words; 'such persons, if any, as may be produced'; cannot substitute 'cited' for 'produced'.

holdings.text: Under s.207A(4) second part, Magistrate may examine other prosecution witnesses if of opinion necessary in interests of justice; judicial discretion reviewable if perverse.

anchor.surface_text: Doubtless the discretion being a judicial one, it should be exercised reasonably by the Magistrate. If he exercises it perversely, it may be liable to be set aside by a superior court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain wording imposes duty only if opinion formed that necessary; discretion judicial hence reasonable and reviewable.

holdings.text: 'Other witnesses' in s.207A(4) includes eye-witnesses not produced by prosecution and other categories.

anchor.surface_text: If so, what do the words other witnesses mean? Do they mean witnesses other than eye-witnesses or witnesses, eye-witnesses or number, other than those produced before the Magistrate, by the prosecution?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Context of witness categories; confers discretion to examine any not produced under first part.

holdings.text: Sub-sections 6 and 7 of s.207A do not impose taking of evidence as condition precedent for commitment or discharge; 'when' denotes time not condition.

anchor.surface_text: It is not permissible to create conflict by construction, when by an alternative construction all the three sub-sections can be harmonized and reconciled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction avoids conflict with sub-s.4 discretion; alternative reading leads to anomaly where documents show innocence but evidence mandatory.

holdings.text: Distinction between procedures under s.207A (sessions) and s.251A (warrant cases) intentional; no obliteration by interpretation.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance is placed upon s. 251A of the Code relating to warrant cases whereunder the Magistrate is authorized, upon consideration of all the documents referred to in s. 173

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.207A requires evidence in contingencies unlike s.251A none; court cannot add conditions.

holdings.text: s.207A interpretation affirmed by Supreme Court precedent in Macherla Hanumantha Rao v. State of Andhra Pradesh: Magistrate not obliged to record evidence, can commit/discharge on documents.

anchor.surface_text: We are fortified in our view by a decision of this Court in Macherla Hanumantha Rao v. The State of Andhra Pradesh... The magistrate then has to record the evidence of such witnesses as figure as eye-witnesses to the occurrence, and are produced before him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly supports view; observations not obiter as necessary for Art.14 analysis.

holdings.text: Magistrate has jurisdiction to commit accused to Sessions without examining any witnesses where prosecution produces none; commitment valid if documents under s.173 sufficient.

anchor.surface_text: Our view companyld number be expressed in the following propositions 1 In a proceeding instituted on a police report, the Magistrate is bound to take evidence of only such eye-witnesses as are actually produced by the prosecution in companyrt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Summarises propositions 1-4 from textual, harmonious interpretation resolving High Court conflicts.

holdings.text: No need to decide whether irregularity in commitment without evidence (if any) is cured by s.537 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: it is not necessary to express our opinion whether even if the Magistrate acted illegally in committing an accused without taking any evidence, the said illegality is cured either by s. 537 of the Code or any other section thereof.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue moot as no illegality found in commitment.

precedents.cited_proposition: Under sub-s. 4 the prosecution is bound to examine all the eye-witnesses indicated in the police report, and the discretion of the Magistrate to examine witnesses under the second part of the said sub-section is only in respect of witnesses other than the eye-witnesses

precedents.cited_proposition: Under sub-s. 4 the prosecution is bound to examine all the eye-witnesses indicated in the police report, and the discretion of the Magistrate to examine witnesses under the second part of the said sub-section is only in respect of witnesses other than the eye-witnesses

anchor.surface_text: Ghisa v. Yasin  1 , In re Pedda Amma Muttigadu  2 , A. Ishaque v. The State  3  and Manik Chand v. The State  4 .

precedents.cited_proposition: The first part confers a power on a Magistrate only to examine the eyewitnesses produced, but the second part empowers him to examine any witness other than those produced, whether eyewitnesses or not, and in a case where the prosecution failed to discharge its duty to produce any witnesses or any important eye-witnesses, the court would not be exercising its judicial discretion if it commits the accused to sessions on the basis of documents referred to under s. 173 of the Code without examining at least the important witnesses

anchor.surface_text: We are fortified in our view by a decision of this Court in Macherla Hanumantha Rao v. The State of Andhra Pradesh  1 . There the point in companytroversy was whether sa. 207 and 207A, inserted in the Code by the Amending Act XXVI of 1955, violated the provisions of Art. 14 of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: Macherla Hanumantha Rao v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: The magistrate then has to record the evidence of such witnesses as figure as eye-witnesses to the occurrence, and are produced before him. He has also the power in the interest of justice, to record such other evidence of the prosecution as he may think necessary, but he is number obliged to record any evidence. Without recording any evidence but after companysidering all the documents referred to in s. 173 and after examining the accused person and after hearing the parties, it is open to the magistrate to discharge the accused person after recording his reasons that number ground for companymitting the accused 1 for trial has been made out
